#Text=Eastern Alberta
#Text=Eastern
#Text=Alberta
#Text=is a region of Alberta , Canada .
#Text=The southern part is an agricultural area , while the north is the focus of Canada 's oil sands industry .
#Text=Cities
#Text=— small lakeside city
#Text=— long a metonym for Canada 's oil sands industry , now rebuilding after a devastating May 2016 wildfire
#Text=— agricultural town that straddles the border with Saskatchewan
#Text=—
#Text=Understand
#Text=This region is primarily agricultural in the south and forested in the north .
#Text=The world famous ( or infamous ) Athabasca Oilsands ( aka the " tar sands " ) are located here .

column1: #Text=The terrain is very flat , but marked by many shallow depressions , many of which are filled with lakes .
#Text=The region in known as Alberta 's " lakeland " , and hunting , sport fishing , and power boating are popular here .
#Text=The region was first populated by indigenous peoples .

#Text=The Chipewyan people ( who are part of the Dene or Athapascan language family ) lived here at the beginnings of European contact ( early 1700s ) , but were soon joined by the Cree people ( from the Algonquian language family ) from the east .

#Text=Both peoples were nomadic and hunted bison ( aka " buffalo " ) on the plains and moose ( aka " elk " ) in the forests and also harvested with many smaller game animals , fish , berries , roots , and so on .

#Text=Descendents of these original peoples , who are called the " First Nations " in Canada , still live in this region and it is possible to attend a " pow-wow " ( a competition or festival centred around traditional music and dancing ) here .
#Text=They were joined by traders from the fur trading companies from England and eastern Canada seeking valuable beaver furs to send to Europe for the hat-making industries .
#Text=The traders took the furs from the native people in exchange for exotic and manufactured goods such as flour , pots , knives , blankets , and so on .
#Text=It is possible to visit several heritage sites related to the fur trade here .

#Text=Relations between the fur traders and the indigenous peoples were mostly peaceful and intermarriage was extremely common , leading to the creation of a new ethnic group , the Métis , of mixed European and indigenous culture and heritage .
#Text=Many of Alberta 's Métis today live in this region , and it is possible to hear their traditional Scottish- and French-influenced music and dance here .

#Text=In 1870 the Hudson 's Bay Company sold its claim over the region to Canada , and Canada then negotiated treaties with the First Nations , confining them to small reserves in exchange for food and medicine ( the bison were nearly extinct by this time due to overhunting ) .
#Text=A promised railway connection to the rest of Canada did not reach anywhere near here until 1891 , when settlers from the rest of Canada and Europe began to arrive in the region .
#Text=This region ( or the southern , agricultural half ) was settled mostly by people of non-British origin , unlike much of Canada and Alberta .
#Text=The area for a time was home to the largest concentrations of Ukrainian people outside of Europe .
#Text=They were joined by many French-Canadians , Germans , Scandinavians , Poles , Romanians , Russians , and so on .

#Text=They were mostly forced to give up their native languages and educate their children in English ( as were the First Nations ) , especially during the paranoia during the First World War when thousands of recent immigrants from the Austro-Hungarian and German Empires were placed in internment camps .
#Text=Nevertheless , there are still many elements of Eastern European culture present here , and it is possible to eat their traditional foods and enjoy a folk dance performance .
#Text=The main industry here for the early settlers was the bulk export of cereal grains , especially wheat , by means of rail .
#Text=The legacy of this are the many heritage sites related to both agriculture and railways that can be seen here .
#Text=Since the 1940s , oil and gas exploration has been the region 's major growth industry .
#Text=Conventional oil and gas continues , by the majority of the investment has shifted north to the oil sands , which are generally mined rather than drilled .
#Text=It is possible to visit a science centre that explains the process in Fort McMurray , the centre of the industry .

#Text=While many locals work in those industries , the repeated sudden oil booms have created labour shortages filled by transient and temporary workers from Eastern Canada and a variety of other countries .
#Text=Whether and how these newcomers will change the communities that long-term settlers and the First Nations have built is an open and unresolved question .
#Text=Talk
#Text=Alberta 's official language is English with some limited rights for the French-speaking minority .
#Text=Nearly everyone here will speak English fluently .

#Text=However , Canadians are from a diverse number of cultures and many are recent immigrants ( or temporary migrant workers ) and you should expect to interact with people whose first language is not English on a regular basis in restaurants and hotels , especially in Fort McMurray .
#Text=A variety of other languages are spoken by individual people .
#Text=However , you should not count on your hotel or other businesses to be able to serve you in any other language .
#Text=They may do so , but it is at their own discretion .

#Text=Offices of the federal government of Canada ( post offices , passport offices , the Royal Canadian Mounted Police , and the national parks ) are required to be able to serve you both English and French , but this does not mean that every employee is fluent in French , especially in this region .
#Text=If you need services in French , you will need to have patience with non-fluent speakers or wait for a French-speaking employee to become available .
#Text=Get in
#Text=The nearest major airport is in Edmonton which has connections to the rest of Canada , the US , Europe , and Asia .
#Text=However Fort McMurray Airport also has connections to most larger Canadian cities and a few places in the United States .
#Text=Regional airports exist in Lloydminster and Cold Lake with connections to Edmonton .

#Text=Via Rail , the national passenger railway , runs through the area but it is an infrequent , slow , and expensive service used mostly by sightseers , passing through on their way to the Rocky Mountains , who rarely stop here .
#Text=For more information see across Canada by rail .
#Text=Likewise , there are several private inter-city bus ( aka " coach " ) companies , but service is limited outside of the larger towns .
#Text=The majority of trips through this region are by private automobile , and many places are only accessible by road .
